12.49.text: I love paper, and I love technology,

16.57.text: and what I do is I make paper interactive.

19.90.text:
And that's what I say when
people ask me what I do,

22.35.text: but it really confuses most people,

24.25.text:
so really, the best way
for me to convey it

26.43.text: is to take the technology and be creative

31.55.text:
So I tried to think
what I could use for here,

33.80.text:
and a couple of weeks
ago I had a crazy idea

35.92.text: that I wanted to print two DJ decks

39.73.text: and to try and mix some music.

42.21.text:
And I'm going to try
and show that at the end,

44.43.text:
and the suspense will be
as much mine if it works.

47.94.text: And I'm not a DJ, and I'm not a musician,

50.60.text: so I'm a little bit scared of that.

53.33.text:
So I think, I found the best
way to describe my journey

58.86.text: is just to mention a few little things

60.51.text:
that have happened to me
throughout my life.

62.61.text:
There's three particular
things that I've done,

64.90.text: and I'll just describe those first,

66.59.text: and then talk about some of my work.

68.61.text:
So when I was a kid,
I was obsessed with wires,

71.84.text: and I used to thread them under my carpet

74.94.text: and thread them behind the walls

76.54.text:
and have little switches
and little speakers,

78.86.text:
and I wanted to make
my bedroom be interactive

81.57.text: but kind of all hidden away.

83.10.text:
And I was also really
interested in wireless as well.

87.14.text:
So I bought one of those
little kits that you could get

91.37.text:
and I got an old book
and I carved out the inside

94.64.text: and I hid it inside there,

96.51.text: and then I placed it next to my dad

98.91.text:
and snuck back to my bedroom
and tuned in on the radio

104.72.text:
I was not at all interested
in what he was saying.

107.13.text: It's more that I just liked the idea

116.83.text:
I managed to successfully
fail all of my exams

120.05.text:
and didn't really leave school
with much to show for at all,

124.77.text: and my parents, maybe as a reward,

128.33.text: bought me what turned out to be

131.90.text:
and I came back home
about four years later.

135.34.text:
I ended up on a farm
in the middle of nowhere.

139.33.text: It was in far western New South Wales.

150.89.text:
And on this farm there
was the farmer, his wife,

153.92.text: and there was the four-year-old daughter.

156.63.text: And they kind of took me into the farm

159.25.text:
and showed me what it
was like to live and work.

162.03.text:
Obviously, one of the most important
things was the sheep,

164.81.text:
and so my job was, well,
pretty much to do everything,

167.75.text:
but it was about bringing
the sheep back to the homestead.

171.15.text: And we'd do that by building fences,

175.69.text:
and the sheep would make
their way all the way back

178.15.text:
to the shearing shed
for the different seasons.

183.86.text: although at the time, like everyone else,

185.96.text: I thought sheep were pretty stupid

187.60.text:
because they didn't do
what we wanted them to do,

189.31.text:
what I realize now, probably
only just in the last few weeks

192.43.text:
looking back, is the sheep
weren't stupid at all.

194.46.text:
We'd put them in an environment
where they didn't want to be,

196.89.text:
and they didn't want to do
what we wanted them to do.

199.44.text: So the challenge was to try and get them

201.86.text: to do what we wanted them to do

202.88.text:
by listening to the weather,
the lay of the land,

205.97.text:
and creating things
that would let the sheep flow

208.98.text: and go where we wanted them to go.

213.29.text: I ended up at Cambridge University

215.64.text: at the Cavendish Laboratory in the U.K.

219.54.text:
My Ph.D. was to move electrons
around, one at a time.

224.56.text:
And I realize — again, it's kind
of these realizations

227.22.text: looking back as to what I did —

229.42.text:
I realize now that it
was pretty much the same

236.46.text:
It's just you do it
by changing an environment.

239.32.text:
And that's kind
of been a big lesson to me,

241.37.text: that you can't act on any object.

242.96.text:
You change its environment,
and the object will flow.

245.51.text: So we made it very small,

247.55.text:
so things were about 30
nanometers in size;

250.44.text:
making it very cold, so
at liquid helium temperatures;

255.24.text:
and changing environment
by changing the voltage,

258.30.text:
and the electrons could
make flow around a loop

261.76.text:
one at a time, on and off,
a little memory node.

264.40.text: And I wanted to go one step further,

266.33.text: and I wanted to move one electron on

270.45.text:
And I was told that I wouldn't
be able to do this,

273.31.text:
which, you know, as we've heard
from other people,

275.33.text: that's the thing that makes you do it.

277.16.text:
And I was determined, and I managed
to show that I could do that.

280.70.text: And a lot of that learning, I think,

282.44.text: came from being on that farm,

283.94.text: because when I was working on the farm,

285.97.text: we'd have to use what was around us,

288.00.text: we'd have to use the environment,

289.79.text: and there was no such thing

292.97.text: because you're in an environment where,

294.86.text: if you can't do what you need to do,

297.07.text: you can die, and, you know,

298.68.text: I had seen that sort of thing happen.

302.41.text: So now my obsession is printing,

305.02.text: and I'm really fascinated by the idea

310.78.text:
so the types of print
that are used to create

313.01.text: many of the things around us

314.36.text: to make paper and card interactive.

318.13.text:
When I spoke to some printers
when I started doing this

320.25.text: and told them what I wanted to do,

321.89.text:
which was to print
conductive inks onto paper,

324.12.text: they told me it couldn't be done,

325.72.text: again, that kind of favorite thing.

327.96.text: So I got about 10 credit cards and loans

332.67.text:
and got myself very close
to bankruptcy, really,

336.17.text:
and bought myself this
huge printing press,

338.26.text: which I had no idea how to use at all.

340.38.text: It was about five meters long,

341.91.text:
and I covered myself
and the floor with ink

344.17.text:
and made a massive mess,
but I learned to print.

347.46.text:
And then I took it back to the printers
and showed them what I've done,

349.99.text:
and they were like, "Of
course you can do that.

352.20.text:
Why didn't you come here
in the first place?"

357.38.text:
So what we do is we take
conventional printing presses,

363.12.text:
and run those through a press,
and basically

366.61.text:
just letting hundreds
of thousands of electrons flow

371.34.text: so we can make that paper interactive.

374.83.text:
It's just a collection of things
that have been done before,

377.69.text:
but bringing them together
in a different way.

379.90.text:
So we have a piece of paper
with conductive ink on,

382.53.text:
and then add onto that a small circuit
board with a couple of chips,

387.14.text: one to run some capacitive touch software,

389.21.text: so we know where we've touched it,

390.85.text: and the other to run, quite often,

393.39.text:
some wireless software so
the piece of paper can connect.

397.35.text:
So I'll just describe a couple
of things that we've created.

400.76.text:
There's lots of different
things we've created.

403.02.text: This is one of them, because I love cake.

405.46.text: And this one, it's a large poster,

408.15.text:
and you touch it and it has
a little speaker behind it,

410.39.text:
and the poster talks
to you when you touch it

412.63.text: and asks you a series of questions,

414.32.text: and it works out your perfect cake.

416.34.text:
But it doesn't tell you
the cake there and then.

420.33.text:
and the reason why it
chose that cake for you,

422.73.text: to our Facebook page and to Twitter.

425.95.text: So we're trying to create that connection

428.78.text: between the physical and the digital,

430.56.text: but have it not looking on a screen,

432.60.text: and just looking like a regular poster.

435.72.text:
We've worked with a bunch
of universities on a project

442.44.text: So for example, we've created a newspaper,

445.89.text:
You can wear a pair of headphones
that are connected to it wirelessly,

448.88.text:
and when you touch it,
you can hear the music

451.05.text:
that's described on the top,
which is something you can't read.

454.07.text: You can hear a press conference

456.24.text:
as well as reading
what the editor has determined

460.33.text: And you can press a Facebook "like" button

462.46.text: or you can vote on something as well.

466.38.text:
and this was an idea that I had
a couple of years ago,

468.65.text: and so we've done a project on this.

469.72.text: It was for funding from the government

471.76.text:
for user-centered design
for energy-efficient buildings,

475.29.text:
difficult to say, and something
I had no idea what it was

477.32.text:
when I went into the workshop,
but quickly learned.

480.10.text: And we wanted to try and encourage people

484.12.text:
And I really liked the idea that,
instead of looking at dials

492.13.text:
I wanted to create a poster
that was wirelessly connected

495.38.text: and had color-changing inks on it,

497.02.text:
and so if your energy usage
was trending better,

500.60.text:
than the leaves would appear
and the rabbits would appear

504.31.text: And if it wasn't, then there'd be graffiti

506.34.text: and the leaves would fall off the trees.

508.27.text:
So it was trying to make
you look after something

512.88.text:
which you don't want to see
not looking so good,

515.37.text: rather than expecting people to do things

517.50.text:
in the local environment
because of the effect

519.81.text: that it has a long way off.

521.29.text:
And I think, kind of like going
back to the farm,

523.64.text:
it's about how to let people
do what you want them to do

526.67.text:
rather than making people do

532.55.text: So this is the bit I'm really scared of.

539.03.text: that you can play drums on.

And I am not a musician. It seemed

If anyone wants to try

This poster is wirelessly

and when you touch it,

It's using Bluetooth 4, so

583.49.text:
so you can touch it, and I just

and this is a software

I'm not a D.J., though, but I just

614.83.text:
So I have a crossfader,

619.72.text: So I've made some new technology,

622.08.text: and I love things being creative,

623.67.text: and I love working with creative people.

629.29.text: and I asked her to record something,

631.48.text: and I worked with a friend called Elliot

634.93.text: So this is my niece, Charlotte.
